ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC GFONT NAME=SAS/GRAPH font| device-resident font | system font mode 
      <display-option(s)> <creation-option(s)>; 

The GFONT procedure displays fonts and creates SAS/GRAPH fonts for use in SAS/GRAPH 
programs. These fonts can contain standard Roman alphabet characters, foreign language 
characters, symbols, logos, or figures. 

You can use the GFONT procedure output when you want to do the following tasks:

  o review the characters that are available in SAS/GRAPH fonts 
  o examine the default device-resident font for your device 
  o see the character codes associated with font characters 
  o view the hexadecimal values associated with font characters 
  o modify the color and height of font characters 
  o draw reference lines around font characters

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NAME=SAS/GRAPH font| device-resident font| system font] 
      
Specifies of theSAS/GRAPH font to be displayed.
Specifies that the GFONT procedure is to display an existing font.

[Syntax: DATA=font-data-set] 
      
Specifies the SAS data set that the GFONT procedure uses to build the font.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
      
Specifies a color for the body of the characters.

[Syntax: GOUT=<libref.>output-catalog] 
      
Specifies the SAS catalog in which to save the graphics output generated by the 
display of the font.

[Syntax: HEIGHT=character-height<units>] 
      
Specifies the height of the font characters in number of units, n.

Specifies that the current key map is ignored when displaying the font and its character 
codes or hexadecimal values.

Turns off the automatic display of character codes that are created when you use the 
SHOWROMAN option during font creation.

Turns off the automatic display of hexadecimal values for single-byte characters that are 
created when you use the ROMHEX option during font creation.

[Syntax: REFCOL=reference-line-color] 
      
Specifies a color for reference lines.
Draws reference lines around each displayed character.

[Syntax: ROMCOL=code-color] 
      
 Specifies the color of the character codes or hexadecimal values that are displayed with 
 the SHOWROMAN and ROMHEX options.

[Syntax: ROMFONT=font] 
      
Specifies the font for character codes and hexadecimal values that are displayed by the 
SHOWROMAN and ROMHEX options.
Displays hexadecimal values below the font characters.

[Syntax: ROMHT=height<units>] 
      
Specifies the height of the character codes and the hexadecimal values that are displayed 
with the SHOWROMAN and ROMHEX options in number of units, n.

Displays the font with a space for every possible character position whether a font character 
exists for that position.

Displays character codes below the font characters even if they are not displayed automatically 
with the font.

[Syntax: BASELINE=y] 
      
Specifies the vertical coordinate in the font data set that is the baseline of the characters.

[Syntax: CAPLINE=y] 
      
Specifies the vertical coordinate in the font data set that is the capline of 
the characters.
Specifies the type of intercharacter spacing.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the first observation for each character sets the width of that character.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Adds a fixed amount of space between characters based on the font size.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that no space is added between characters.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that the amount of space that is used for each character is uniform, not proportional.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the length in bytes of the CHAR variable. To specify double-byte character sets 
for languages such as Chinese, Japanese, or Korean, use CODELEN=2.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a single-byte length CHAR variable
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a double-byte length CHAR variable.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that the characters in a polygon font are filled.

[Syntax: KERNDATA=kern-data-set] 
      
Specifies the data set that contains kerning information.

[Syntax: MWIDTH=character-width] 
      
Specifies the width of a character in a uniform font, where character-width is the number 
of font units.
Specifies that the GFONT procedure is not to display the font that it is creating.

Controls the resolution of the fonts by specifying the number of bytes (1 through 4) for 
storing coordinates in the font.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: 32,766 distinct points; works well for most applications
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: 2,147,483,646 distinct points; might be too dense to be practical
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: 2,147,483,646 distinct points; might be too dense to be practical

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: SPACEDATA=space-data-set] 
      
Specifies the SAS data set that contains font spacing information.
Specifies that characters are spaced uniformly rather than proportionately.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: NOTE <text-arguments(s)>; 
      
Controls the content, appearance, and placement of text. 

text-argument(s) can be one or more of these: 

 "text-string"
 
 text-options (text options must precede text-string.)

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANGLE=degrees | A=degrees] 
          
Specifies the angle of the baseline of the entire text string with respect to the 
horizontal. A positive degrees value angles the baseline counterclockwise; a negative 
value angles it clockwise. By default, ANGLE=0 (horizontal).

[Syntax: BCOLOR=background-color] 
          
Specifies the background color of a box produced by the BOX= option. If you omit 
BOX=, BCOLOR= is ignored. By default, the background color of the box is the same 
as the background color for the entire graph. The color of the frame of the box is 
determined by the color specification used in BOX=.

[Syntax: BLANK=YES] 
          
Protects the box and its contents from being overwritten by any subsequent graphics elements
by blanking out the area where the box is displayed. The BLANK= option enables you to overlay 
graphics elements with boxed text. It is ignored if you omit the BOX= option. Because titles 
and footnotes are written from the highest numbered to the lowest numbered, the BLANK= option 
only blanks out titles and footnotes of a lower number.
Draws a box around one line of text.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: A value of 1 produces the thinnest box lines.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: A value of 2 produces the next thinnest box lines.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: A value of 3 produces the next thickest box lines.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: A value of 4 produces the thickest box lines.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BSPACE=box-space<units>] 
          
Specifies the amount of space between the boxed text and the box. The space above the text is 
measured from the font maximum, and the space below the text is measured from the font minimum.
By default, BSPACE=1. If the BOX= option is not used, the BSPACE= option is ignored.

[Syntax: COLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color for the following text, box, or line. The COLOR= option affects 
all text, lines, and boxes that follow it and stays in effect until another COLOR= 
specification is encountered.

[Syntax: DRAW=(x,y...,x-n,y-n)<units>] 
          
Draws lines anywhere on the graphics output area using x and y as absolute or 
relative coordinates.

[Syntax: FONT=font] 
          
Specifies the font for the subsequent text.

[Syntax: HEIGHT=text-height<units>] 
          
Specifies the height of text characters in number of units. By default, HEIGHT=1. 
Height is measured from the font minimum to the capline. Ascenders can extend above 
the capline, depending on the font.
Specifies the alignment of the text string. The default is LEFT.

[Syntax: LANGLE=degrees] 
          
Specifies the angle of the baseline of the entire text string(s) with respect to 
the horizontal. A positive value for degrees moves the baseline counterclockwise; 
a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, LANGLE=0 (horizontal).

[Syntax: LINK= "URL"] 
          
Specifies a uniform resource locator (URL) that a title or footnote links to. The 
text-string that you use to specify the URL can contain occurrences of the variables 
#BYVAL, #BYVAR, and #BYLINE.

[Syntax: LSPACE=line-space <units>] 
          
Specifies the amount of spacing above lines of note and title text and the amount 
of spacing below lines of footnote text.

[Syntax: MOVE=(x,y) <units>] 
          
Positions subsequent text or lines anywhere on the graphics output area using x and y 
as absolute or relative coordinates.

[Syntax: ROTATE=degrees] 
          
Specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated with respect to the 
baseline of the text string. The angle is measured from the current text baseline 
angle, which is specified by the ANGLE= or LANGLE= options. By default, the baseline 
is horizontal. A positive value for degrees rotates the character counterclockwise; 
a negative value rotates it clockwise. By default, ROTATE=0 (parallel to the baseline).

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: UNDERLIN=0 halts underlining for subsequent text.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Undelines with the next thickest line.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Wraps the text to a second line if the text does not fit on one line. If the WRAP 
option is omitted, the text font-size is reduced until the text fits on one line. 
Wrapping occurs at the last blank before the text meets the end of the window. If 
there are no blanks in the text string, then there is no wrapping.
